medical: PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Recurrent right inguinal hernia, as well as phimosis. POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: Recurrent right inguinal hernia, as well as phimosis. PROCEDURE PERFORMED: Laparoscopic right inguinal herniorrhaphy with mesh, as well as a circumcision. ANESTHESIA: General endotracheal. COMPLICATIONS: None. DISPOSITION: The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to recovery room in stable condition. SPECIMEN: Foreskin. BRIEF HISTORY: This patient is a 66-year-old African-American male who presented to Dr. Y's office with recurrent right inguinal hernia for the second time requesting hernia repair. The procedure was discussed with the patient and the patient opted for laparoscopic repair due to multiple attempts at the open inguinal repair on the right. The patient also is requesting circumcision with phimosis at the same operating time setting. INTRAOPERATIVE FINDINGS: The patient was found to have a right inguinal hernia with omentum and bowel within the hernia, which was easily reduced. The patient was also found to have a phimosis, which was easily removed. PROCEDURE: After informed consent, the risks and benefits of the procedure were explained to the patient. The patient was brought to operating suite, after general endotracheal intubation, prepped and draped in the normal sterile fashion. An infraumbilical incision was made with a #15 Bard-Parker scalpel. The umbilical skin was elevated with a towel clip and the Veress needle was inserted without difficulty. Saline drop test proved entrance into the abdominal cavity and then the abdomen was insufflated to sufficient pressure of 15 mmHg. Next, the Veress was removed and #10 bladed trocar was inserted without difficulty. The 30-degree camera laparoscope was then inserted and the abdomen was explored. There was evidence of a large right inguinal hernia, which had omentum as well as bowel within it, easily reducible. Attention was next made to placing a #12 port in the right upper quadrant, four fingerbreadths from the umbilicus. Again, a skin was made with a #15 blade scalpel and the #12 port was inserted under direct visualization. A #5 port was inserted in the left upper quadrant in similar fashion without difficulty under direct visualization. Next, a grasper with blunt dissector was used to reduce the hernia and withdraw the sac and using an Endoshears, the peritoneum was scored towards the midline and towards the medial umbilical ligament and lateral. The peritoneum was then spread using the blunt dissector, opening up and identifying the iliopubic tract, which was identified without difficulty. Dissection was carried out, freeing up the hernia sac from the peritoneum. This was done without difficulty reducing the hernia in its entirety. Attention was next made to placing a piece of Prolene mesh, it was placed through the #12 port and placed into the desired position, stapled into place in its medial aspect via the 4 mm staples along the iliopubic tract. The 4.8 mm staples were then used to staple the superior edge of the mesh just below the peritoneum and then the patient was re-peritonealized, re-approximating edge of the perineum with the 4.8 mm staples. This was done without difficulty. All three ports were removed under direct visualization. No evidence of bleeding and the #10 and #12 mm ports were closed with #0-Vicryl and UR6 needle. Skin was closed with running subcuticular #4-0 undyed Vicryl. Steri-Strips and sterile dressings were applied. Attention was next made to carrying out the circumcision. The foreskin was retracted back over the penis head. The desired amount of removing foreskin was marked out with a skin marker. The foreskin was then put on tension using a clamp to protect the penis head. A #15 blade scalpel was used to remove the foreskin and sending off as specimen. This was done without difficulty. Next, the remaining edges were retracted, hemostasis was obtained with Bovie electrocautery and the skin edges were re-approximated with #2-0 plain gut in simple interrupted fashion and circumferentially. This was done without difficulty maintaining hemostasis. A petroleum jelly was applied with a Coban dressing. The patient tolerated this procedure well and was well and was transferred to recovery after extubation in stable condition.
layman:
**Pre‑operative diagnosis:**  
The patient had a right groin hernia that had come back after a previous repair, and he also had a tight foreskin (phimosis).

**Post‑operative diagnosis:**  
The same conditions – a recurrent right groin hernia and phimosis.

**Procedure performed:**  
A laparoscopic repair of the right groin hernia using a mesh, plus a circumcision.

**Anesthesia:**  
General anesthesia with a breathing tube (endotracheal).

**Complications:**  
None.

**Disposition:**  
The patient tolerated the surgery well and was moved to the recovery room in stable condition.

**Specimen:**  
Foreskin tissue removed during the circumcision.

**Brief history:**  
A 66‑year‑old African‑American man came to Dr. Y’s office because his right groin hernia had returned for the second time. He wanted a laparoscopic repair because he had already had two open repairs on that side. He also asked for a circumcision because of his tight foreskin. The surgeon explained the risks and benefits, and the patient agreed to the surgery.

**Intra‑operative findings:**  
During the operation the surgeon saw a right groin hernia that contained omentum (fatty tissue) and bowel, but it could be pushed back easily. The tight foreskin was also found and could be removed easily.

**Procedure details:**  
After the patient was given general anesthesia and the breathing tube was placed, the surgeon cleaned and covered the area with sterile drapes.  
A small incision was made below the belly button with a #15 scalpel. A Veress needle was inserted to confirm entry into the abdomen, and the abdomen was inflated with gas to 15 mmHg. The Veress needle was removed and a #10 trocar was inserted. A 30‑degree camera was then used to look inside. The surgeon saw the large right groin hernia with omentum and bowel, which was easily reduced.  
A second port (#12) was placed in the upper right abdomen, and a third port (#5) was placed in the upper left abdomen. Using a grasper and blunt dissector, the hernia sac was pulled out and the peritoneum (the lining of the abdomen) was cut toward the midline and the iliopubic tract. The sac was freed from the peritoneum and removed.  
A piece of Prolene mesh was inserted through the #12 port and positioned over the hernia defect. It was secured with 4‑mm staples along the iliopubic tract and with 4.8‑mm staples along the top edge just below the peritoneum. The peritoneum was then closed over the mesh with the same staples. All three ports were removed while watching the inside of the abdomen. No bleeding was seen. The #10 and #12 ports were closed with #0 Vicryl sutures and the skin was closed with a running subcuticular #4‑0 Vicryl stitch. Steri‑Strips and dressings were applied.

The surgeon then performed the circumcision. The foreskin was pulled back over the head of the penis, the amount to be removed was marked, and a clamp was used to protect the penis. A #15 scalpel was used to cut the foreskin, which was sent as a specimen. The remaining edges were pulled back, bleeding was stopped with electrocautery, and the skin was stitched together with #2‑0 plain gut in simple interrupted stitches around the entire circumference. A petroleum jelly ointment was applied and a Coban dressing was placed.  
The patient tolerated the entire procedure well and was taken to recovery after the breathing tube was removed, remaining stable.
